snippet.textDisplay:
For beginners, something thats really helped me when one on one battles especially against knights. 
Ashes of War: barricade shield

This allows you to break the enemy stance when you block their attack. From here you can go right into a guard counter and deal good damage. If you get a couple more hits in right after your guard counter u can put knights on their knees and dominate them with a critical. This is my go to for fighting knights. Use a shield with 100% dmg negation, and you are set.
snippet.textOriginal:
For beginners, something thats really helped me when one on one battles especially against knights.

This allows you to break the enemy stance when you block their attack. From here you can go right into a guard counter and deal good damage. If you get a couple more hits in right after your guard counter u can put knights on their knees and dominate them with a critical. This is my go to for fighting knights. Use a shield with 100% dmg negation, and you are set.

snippet.textDisplay:
This game should be advertised as a survival game. 
First 4 hours of gameplay and all i do is either skip around big enemies or cheese everything else with my horse. Currently finding weapons which i need more strength to use and dying randomly in 1-2 hits from ridiculous attacks or flaming giant arrows. 
Being a tactical shooter buff, cs/valorant/even cod, this game is painfully boring. I love fast paced, heartpounding clutch moments, this game is the complete opposite. Slow, grindy, loot heavy bs. Target lock is annoying. Im going to randomly play to keep trying to progress, but for people who like sports and competition, this game is ..... uhh, idk man. It seems like a well put together game, but this is not my cup of tea.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have been obsessed with the starting class. I'm only 120h into the game and this is my conclusions, but I'm looking for either affirmation or corrections on these if you wouldn't mind stopping to read.

Warrior: Main melee DPS and Keen Ash of war mastery. Does well to punish large enemies with big recovery times. Best used as a Cooperative Finger if the host is a Confessor or Vagabond. 

Samurai: Attacks at every single opening possible making it the most consistent dps of all classes, never needing to pause for a break due to its high stamina. Sacrifices versatility of the Vagabond class in exchange for higher DPS and an immediate ranged option.  Struggles against heavy armored opponents due to the lack of staggering power and enemies immune to bleed. A contender arcane for amplifying it's bleed katana and dragon spells, but not much use for its discovery since it's starting armery is all you need.

Vagabond: Highest HP of all classes. Widest range arsenal. Best suited against human and middle sized bosses. This class is most likely to do the most exploring as they can equip armaments to deal with anything.

Bandit: easily amasses resources from dispatching lackies and has dragon sorceries for bosses. He can opt to go into the caves anyway to quickly max out multiple weapons for the highest early game power spike.

Hero: Highest stance damage of all classes. Not quite as tanky as the Vagabond. Deals with above human sized bosses. Can make space for other cooperative fingers to recover through repeated stance breaking and parrying. Excellent at absorbing sorceries and incantation damage. A surprising arcane stat that hints, like the bandit, may be possible to use dragon spells together with their brute force.

Confessor: The ultimate all around class; the widest arsenal and adaptability. Bloody Finger specialist after the holy immunity cut off in the mid game. 

Prophet: Ultimate support Cooperative Finger. High burst damage and heals. Can choose incantations that bosses are weak to. No incantations are above their reach.

Prisoner: superior combat advantage in a 1v1, high colosseum ranking. Has trouble dealing with multiple targets and opponents with high poise. One man damage machine.

Astrologer: Backline caster. Highest sustainable ranged DPS of all classes. Will not survive the lands between without the use of spirits, summons, and Cooperative Fingers.

snippet.textDisplay:
If you enjoyed Elden Ring and are new to Soulsborne I highly suggest you make your next game the original Dark Souls. 

DS1 is what separates the men from the boys. You‚Äôll be overwhelmed with that sense of accomplishment from doing basic things like landing a backstab or reaching the next bonfire.

You will meet your first Black Knight and you will die. Then you will meet the Taurus Demon and you will die. You might reach the first bell but you‚Äôll die some more. Hell, you might even make it to Blight Town where you‚Äôll probably just uninstall the game.

If you don‚Äôt uninstall it‚Äôll eventually click and you‚Äôll become obsessed like the rest of us more seasoned players. 

These games are some of the greatest video games ever made. I‚Äôve never experienced a sense of accomplishment from beating a game like I did when I finally defeated Gywn. Piece of advice, parry him. Thank me later.
snippet.textOriginal:
If you enjoyed Elden Ring and are new to Soulsborne I highly suggest you make your next game the original Dark Souls. 

DS1 is what separates the men from the boys. You‚Äôll be overwhelmed with that sense of accomplishment from doing basic things like landing a backstab or reaching the next bonfire.

You will meet your first Black Knight and you will die. Then you will meet the Taurus Demon and you will die. You might reach the first bell but you‚Äôll die some more. Hell, you might even make it to Blight Town where you‚Äôll probably just uninstall the game.

If you don‚Äôt uninstall it‚Äôll eventually click and you‚Äôll become obsessed like the rest of us more seasoned players. 

These games are some of the greatest video games ever made. I‚Äôve never experienced a sense of accomplishment from beating a game like I did when I finally defeated Gywn. Piece of advice, parry him. Thank me later.

snippet.textDisplay:
for absolute beginners who don't know, locking on is R3, you have to press the right stick on your controller so it clicks.
something that really tripped me up when i was new to fromsoft games: if you're fighting multiple enemies, don't lock on, either manually move your camera with the right stick (in order to dodge and control the camera simultaneously, you may need to do a claw grip on your controller, i.e. hit the A button with your index finger), or click your left stick to center the camera behind you periodically. 
fortunately, spacing is much more important than rolling when you're fighting multiple enemies, so you usually won't need to use a claw grip.
there's also some controllers, some really good third party ones like the 8bitdo pro 2 or mobapad chitu hd, which have buttons on the back that you can bind to your dodge button so you can control camera and dodge simultaneously without claw grip.
snippet.textOriginal:

something that really tripped me up when i was new to fromsoft games: if you're fighting multiple enemies, don't lock on, either manually move your camera with the right stick (in order to dodge and control the camera simultaneously, you may need to do a claw grip on your controller, i.e. hit the A button with your index finger), or click your left stick to center the camera behind you periodically. 
fortunately, spacing is much more important than rolling when you're fighting multiple enemies, so you usually won't need to use a claw grip.
there's also some controllers, some really good third party ones like the 8bitdo pro 2 or mobapad chitu hd, which have buttons on the back that you can bind to your dodge button so you can control camera and dodge simultaneously without claw grip.

snippet.textDisplay: The game is a joke, except I'm not laughing spending 40 bucks on an unplayable game. I don't care that the game "doesn't hold your hand" or that it "gives a sense of adventure." And I'm tired of the game getting all these glowing reviews. And I refuse to read a manual or watching hours of YouTube videos, unless it's one on how to get my money back. The game refuses to let my character feel like I'm advancing. I found a sword and mace, but couldn't use it because I lacked strength or dexterity. Couldn't engage in ANY combat without dying a million times. I'll let the fan boys descend from the mountain and tell me how to play this game because I stopped caring long ago. Burns me because I usually never spend 40 bucks on any game. As far as "Western developers being afraid" y'all ain't got nothing to worry about. Loved Skyrim, but this game is horrible. HORRIBLE!

snippet.textDisplay: I started my console career back in 1986 with Sega Master System. Owned and played nearly all brands and types of consoles, usually busy with rpgs. In the last decade i found my gaming destination  in soulslike games. As an experienced old fart player, i can state: ER is in terms of atmosphere and world design incredible, sometimes it made me speechless. A masterpiece, a gaming monument And it will continue, this is really good news. If i try to find some criticism i would name the repeated design of dungeons and the missing rewards in colosseum pvp. I have no clue why GOW Ragnarok is seen as a competition. IMHO it‚Äòs not even close.
snippet.textOriginal: I started my console career back in 1986 with Sega Master System. Owned and played nearly all brands and types of consoles, usually busy with rpgs. snippet.textDisplay: I just started playing this game on Steam and I pick Mouse/Keyboard (I have a controller but decide not to use it) .... Honestly it was a mistake, the combat keybinding is really confusing as many of them share the same key and sometimes same function but it uses different key depending on your weapon, for some reason and so on. In a panic of combat, I often use item instead of a spell, or use spell instead of weapon skill, or 2 handing shield instead of my halberd, or use weapon skill instead of guard countering and thrust off the cliffside into the depth. Now I'm starting to familiar with keyboard I'm too lazy to relearn on controller now.
snippet.textOriginal: I just started playing this game on Steam and I pick Mouse/Keyboard (I have a controller but decide not to use it) .... snippet.textDisplay:
Some more tips not mentioned. Sorry I'm late.

1] Most smithing stones for upgrading armaments can eventually be purchased infinitely once you acquire a special item called a "Stone Bell Bearing". These are exchanged at round table hold with an npc who sells useful things. Once you give the npc a stone bell bearing, they'll sell you unlimited smithing stones corresponding to the tier of the stone bell bearing.

Look for small circular symbols on the map with a slightly orange highlight, they indicates its a cave. Stone bell bearings are mostly found in caves. And more difficult areas give you higher tier bell bearings to exchange.

What this means is that contradictory to what was said in the guide, you can actually upgrade as many weapons as you want later on, so don't be scared, it is not a finite resource.

2] A good indication that your dodge roll is going to be fast enough and that your armour isn't too heavy for your character is that you'll see it says "Light, mid or heavy" under your weight category. If it says "heavy" then your armour is going to slow your dodge roll. Forget the 70% thing. Just read that tool tip. If you equip armour and it knocks up your weight load to heavy, consider leaving it unequipped until you've got enough endurance stat to carry more. Also regarding weight, if you equip multiple armaments, it adds to your weight, even when you switch out the armaments. So while it might seem cool n fancy to have so many weapon slots, it might not be practical to use them all. Stick to one or two weapons.

3] You can backstab if you "light attack" an enemy from behind or "critical strike" them if you light attack them from the front after you break their armour  and they become briefly wounded. Eventually you'll get a talisman that can heal you whenever you get a critical strike, which helps immensely with sustaining your health during long encounters and you don't want to use all your flasks.

4] Your actual inventory is limitless and adds no weight to your character. So don't be scared to hoard up all your findings. There really is no need for a stash in Elden ring (although there is one if that's your thing)

5] Don't immediately use/sell your golden runes. Stockpile them until they're required. You'll lose your currency on death, but runes are kept. I made the mistake of selling all of mine for about 130k and  died shortly afterwards. Losing it all :(.
When I could have just kept them in the inventory and sold them off when I was in a safer location and could level up or spend them for items.

6] if your gonna play a melee focused build, regardless of strength or dexterity, consider investing most of your early attributes on Vigor first. You'll need the health, TRUST ME.

your damage scaling should mostly come from armament upgrades in the early game that's more than enough. Won't be until later you start dropping it all on your damage scaling stat. (Str/dex) based on weapon.

Feel free to add more tips here in the reply section to my comment.

Cheers & have a good one

snippet.textDisplay: I‚Äôve never played a souls game and just picked up a PS5 so I dove head first into Elden ring. So far I‚Äôm absolutely loving it, it‚Äôs so incredibly cryptic in terms of not guiding the player or explaining much which I actually love and find very refreshing. So many games now spend the first chunk of the game hand holding for every little function, the gameplay reminds me of NES games where you just start the game and figure out what to do for yourself. My only gripe was not having played a souls game before I was overwhelmed with feeling like I was missing out like I had to have played one of the previous games to get the lore or understand what to do but I‚Äôm about 5 hours in now and I‚Äôm hooked.

My suggestions:
-upgrade your weapons as soon as you can 
-increase your stats according to your style and dont forget to increase intelligence even if you are not a magician 
-Farm in zones you feel secure and gives you good experience according to your level 
-Use 2 hands in your melee weapons
all this worked for me , of course there are many more things to do like equip talismans and get weapons with passive effects, ashes of war and so on

snippet.textDisplay:
My PS4 notes from this video.  ALSO SEE THE YOUTUBE TRANSCRIPT.
Cycle thru weapons with left or right on D-pad.
CRIMSON TEARS  should be default down on D-pad.
Horse ring whistle:  hit triangle and cycle thru to find it.

To recover lost Runes from amidst a lot of enemies, run towards them.  As they attack jump on horse.  You have several invincible frames.  Ride to runes and collect.  

Section 3 is how to fight.  R3 to lock on.  Raie shield with L1.  With a shield L1 block their light attacks.  Lower shield after blocking.  Try to anticipate a heavy attack and roll our of way.  

Block light atks.  Roll thru heavy atks. 

FOR ALL ENEMIES.  Wait for a lite atk. Block. R2 to heavy atk. 
===
FLASK OF CRIMSON TEARS replenishes health.  Refilled at grace points. 
Small red rolling balls of thorns replenish flasks.  Killing gangs of monsters too.  Golden Seeds are found at Light Trees.  Golden Seens increase the number of flasks you can carry. 

CRIMSON TEARS  should be default down on D-pad.

SACRED TEARS increase teh amount of healing each flask does. 
===

MOUNTED COMBAT
L1 L2 R1 R2 to use weapon on each side.
L2 R2 can charge up 
The first boss, mounted Tree Keep shoudl be fought with hit and run attacks, not circling engagement. 

Can jump OFF horse with L3 and jump on a wolf for a surprise atk.  When on foot, L3 is crouch.
===
ARCHERY

===
POWER STANCING - 2 of same weapon,
Enables a special L1 atk, a jump then a combo 
Jumping atks are gap closers for spear and pike enemies and big bats.

snippet.textDisplay: So as a fellow objective follower (go here, do this, go there, do that), I was stumped at how open Elden Ring was. Like it was open-open. The first few hours were painful, excruciating. I wanted to quit but I kept seeing these gameplay videos especially Vaatividya's and kept coming back. I kept dying. And it was no fun. The more I played the more "I got gud" (but not gud enough) thus I spend countless hours just exploring, finding new stuff, levelling up. Eventually I learnt the surroundings, the enemy move sets, it started to touch more Sites of Grace, and  the Sites of Grace seem to be "pointing" or rather implying the direction I need for progression (story-wise). Interestingly, it started to click for me and I'm happy to say I'm at Crumbling Farum Azula (yes, bough the game when released but I'm rather slow lol). Also, is it me or the deeper I progress in the map it seem to become more "linear" (still open but the design seems to be more tight). Overall I have to say, this truly is one of the best games I've played. The game can actually mold your character (in real life lol) with things like dealing with defeats, being patient, how thorough you are in exploring, willingness to learn. I can see how this game won't appeal to other objective followers but with time, you are likely going to enjoy it.

The more I played the more "I got gud" (but not gud enough) thus I spend countless hours just exploring, finding new stuff, levelling up. Eventually I learnt the surroundings, the enemy move sets, it started to touch more Sites of Grace, and  the Sites of Grace seem to be "pointing" or rather implying the direction I need for progression (story-wise). Also, is it me or the deeper I progress in the map it seem to become more "linear" (still open but the design seems to be more tight). Overall I have to say, this truly is one of the best games I've played. The game can actually mold your character (in real life lol) with things like dealing with defeats, being patient, how thorough you are in exploring, willingness to learn. snippet.textDisplay: i tried out Elden Ring and just couldnt get into it after 2 hours of play, which is plenty of time for me to gage any game, great games of the past got me hooked in 20 minutes. i then remember i never played the Witcher 3 expansions and so I went back and instantly fell in love with that game again. I think for me the different is the character and story, i like Geralt and the world around him, I like having a main character to attach to but with Elden Ring it just felt like another generic fantasy world and i was no body special running around in it.  I have 3 young kids and if im going to invest any amount of time into a game its needs to have a fun story and Elden Ring just didnt do it for me. Sure combat and gameplay was good but maybe if it has a defined protagonist instead of create your own character id be more into it. This same reason is why i like the Far Cry and Mass effect series so much, they are character and story driven.

snippet.textDisplay: A game being super hard doesn't make it a good game. Elden Ring is good, but, many times it feels it's hard just for the sake of being hard. Not everyone has hundreds of hours to "master" a single game. People have jobs and want to play videogames to DE-stress, not to pull out their hair after a long day at work.
snippet.textOriginal: A game being super hard doesn't make it a good game. Elden Ring is good, but, many times it feels it's hard just for the sake of being hard. Not everyone has hundreds of hours to "master" a single game. People have jobs and want to play videogames to DE-stress, not to pull out their hair after a long day at work.

snippet.textDisplay: One more key tip: You do NOT have to fight everything, it‚Äôs okay to run away from the big baddies and come back when you‚Äôre stronger. I spent the first three hours of my playthrough trying to kill the Tree Sentinel and made no progress.

snippet.textDisplay: These souls games are only good for one thing.  Unbalanced.  It goes back to the first harder games.  Like "Battletoads" .  People hated it because it was so hard but played it anyway.  This game is worse than that.  Take the one shot kills and unbalanced enemies out and it's an average game at best.    I never cared for any souls game and like challenging games no doubt.   But Bandia Namco published games always seemed cheaply designed and clunky like the soul games.

snippet.textDisplay:
One thing I see rarely get attention is Rainbow Stones. Tossing one off a ledge will let you know if it's safe to drop. If it explodes, you won't survive. If you see a colorful rock, then you will. 

It's also really good to use when you're exploring around to let you know where you've been. Even I, a veteran of the Soulsborn games, sometimes got lost while playing by running through previously explored areas. Dropping a stone at junctions or forks in the road, or in branching cave systems, is always a good idea.
snippet.textOriginal:
One thing I see rarely get attention is Rainbow Stones. Tossing one off a ledge will let you know if it's safe to drop. If it explodes, you won't survive. If you see a colorful rock, then you will. 

It's also really good to use when you're exploring around to let you know where you've been. Even I, a veteran of the Soulsborn games, sometimes got lost while playing by running through previously explored areas. Dropping a stone at junctions or forks in the road, or in branching cave systems, is always a good idea.

snippet.textDisplay:
Somehow, I missed the hype train entirely for this game and just got my hands on it. 
Don't get me wrong, I fancied myself many an hour in DS-2&3 but somehow life and other games had my attention until I found that this had already been out about a month or two.

snippet.textDisplay: Small piece of advice for handling your mount: in order to double-jump, you have to *jump* first. Falling doesn't enable it. If you fall off a cliff while riding your steed, you won't be able to double-jump because the game registers falling as being different from jumping. Instead, if you want to double-jump near a landing spot below, you have to make sure you *jump* off the ledge, not just run off.
snippet.textOriginal: Small piece of advice for handling your mount: in order to double-jump, you have to *jump* first. Falling doesn't enable it. If you fall off a cliff while riding your steed, you won't be able to double-jump because the game registers falling as being different from jumping. Instead, if you want to double-jump near a landing spot below, you have to make sure you *jump* off the ledge, not just run off.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm 11 hours into this game, LV 30, and yes I understand that's very little and I have not seen much of it, but my experience so far is far from giving the game 10/10, in fact not even a 5. All I'm hearing is people just like what I have done here going on Youtube and getting tips and tricks about the game. Has anyone played this game without getting any help? And why should a gamer be getting/outsourcing help to play a game? The design of the game is such that it is forcing the gamer to do what is not necessary to cheat the game and I think that is destroying the experience. 

I have not found the game frustrating or hard at all, but I found myself asking "Why?" a lot? For example, why is the map so large and filled with a great deal of emptiness? People call it exploring but exploring what exactly? Why do we game to explore open fields with nothing in them except an occasional guard, wolf, overgrown bat, or some creature?

The game has caused thousands of people to create videos online of how to kill what boss, how to farm runes, how to do that, this and that... and thus millions search for these videos. Basically, the game is forcing people to find ways to cheat the game itself. A gamer should be playing a game not searching online on how to play it. The funny thing is these people are giving the game 10/10 after spending the entire game looking at websites and Youtube for help. Definitely would not recommend this game to anyone, and don't trick yourself by saying "Souls games are like this...". If the game was set out to do what it should fewer people would be spending time online and more in the game playing.

snippet.textDisplay:
As a rule of thumb new players should know this:
1.- If you are hitting a boss and doing very little damage, you need to come back later to that boss. Get good gear, weapons, and skills, then come back and fight it. You should be killing a boss in 10 to 20 hits to have a decent gaming experience. 

If you are hitting a boss and doing very little damage, then don't waste your time, the boss rank is too high for you and you need better gear.
snippet.textOriginal:
As a rule of thumb new players should know this:
1.- If you are hitting a boss and doing very little damage, you need to come back later to that boss. Get good gear, weapons, and skills, then come back and fight it. You should be killing a boss in 10 to 20 hits to have a decent gaming experience. 

If you are hitting a boss and doing very little damage, then don't waste your time, the boss rank is too high for you and you need better gear.

snippet.textDisplay:
This gotta be the most overhyped game of all time. I wonder how people find Cyberprank bad and this piece of game-dev "amazing 10/10 goty must play".

The game has so little to offer even though it has open world. Nothing amusing, worthy or at least a little various. Mobs, mobs, smaller mobs, bigger mobs, bosses - that is ALL.

Absolutely no evolution from the first Souls game in terms of gameplay and mechanics.
The most annoying part is that bosses and mini-bosses don't react to your actions whatsoever. They just do not care what you are doing. They got hit? Who cares? You blocked their attack? Nothing. It's like you don't even exist to them, so you are just playing with yourself really.

Hot overrated garbage in my book. The only good part is graphics and the world design.

snippet.textDisplay: "block fast attacks, dodge slow attacks" it's exactly the opposite with a high stamina/poise build because so many "slow" attacks have an arbitrarily long windup and instant launch that it's dangerous to mistime dodging, but if you can keep your stance through them then you usually have an opening to counterattack - while blocking fast attacks whittles down your stamina so you have less of it for said big attacks.
snippet.textOriginal: "block fast attacks, dodge slow attacks" it's exactly the opposite with a high stamina/poise build because so many "slow" attacks have an arbitrarily long windup and instant launch that it's dangerous to mistime dodging, but if you can keep your stance through them then you usually have an opening to counterattack - while blocking fast attacks whittles down your stamina so you have less of it for said big attacks.

snippet.textDisplay: I am also a beginner in the game, but there is one tip I would like to add. Don't buy the ringmail armor set from the first vendor... I wasted 4500 runes for it, but it is much more efficient to just grind the nearby forest and the camp. There you can also get a medium armour, a lot of base typ weapons, and most importantly a lot of runes to level up... The only important stuff is the crafting tool, which also can refinance itself and the crafting recipes.
snippet.textOriginal: I am also a beginner in the game, but there is one tip I would like to add. Don't buy the ringmail armor set from the first vendor... I wasted 4500 runes for it, but it is much more efficient to just grind the nearby forest and the camp. snippet.textDisplay:
So you have to have A (excuse my French) Consol Controller to play this. 
So its really just a speed game with good graphics made for the 6 year old intellect. Sorry, I didn't mean to offend. I played WOW, and Disciples 2 forever. It was like Checkers and Chess.
WOW had some of this mentality in it, but you didn't need to have a console controller to play it. 
So I guess what I am getting at is this is more like a First Person Shooter, except with Swords, Bows, and Spells, but the combat is 80 to 100% melee. You can't be a Wizard in here and beat anyone.
Well that settles the class war that was in World of Warcraft. They couldn't ever balance the classes because it was to complicated. They did try though and come close depending on how you played it. 
This might be alright on PVE, if you can play it that way without PPE. It might be ok if you like the speed combat. I personally don't care for it.
I haven't played Raid either because of the Pay to Win system in it. I do like the graphics in this, and the armor looks more real and not Cosplay. Of course I am just watching this one video so this might have some Black Desert in it also.
Anyway. TY for the vid.

snippet.textDisplay:
Appreciate the guide! Started today without knowing anything besides than it's a Souls game. Having never played one of them before I naturally picked the Wrench, removed the Keepsake from my starter equipment and used Mouse & Keyboard. I think I'm a masochist.

snippet.textDisplay:
Stamina is very forgiving in this game.
Blocking and dodging are sometimes never an option. I've come across one enemy that will destroy your stamina if you bock and will overcome any dodge you try to do. I'm hoping there is something somewhere that either extends the invincibility frames  (which is such a crap mechanic imo), extends the dodge roll distance, or provides some means to withstand this enemy's relentless assaults.  This is not even a boss. Best tactic so far is to pound the thing with spells and hope to kill it before its upon me. This will come easier as I level up my stat for that spell.
In my experience, if a foe can one shot me, and I can't do the same in return, I am under equipped and under leveled. If I am unable to get to that point within reasonable effort, it's a badly designed game. I shouldn't need to grind for days to match my opponent (Darks Souls games, Demon Souls, and Bloodborne). A damage sponge enemy is lack of creativity from the developers, and overall bad design.  

18:29 Is that what those are supposed to signify? I've been exploring all over the place and have seen these. 

That item you need for co-oping, you are going to want to craft those since finding them is not all that plentiful. I've come across 1 in my entire venture. There's far better guides on multiplayer than this video. 

This video is really good overall. I even learned some things.

snippet.textDisplay: Disappointed: I heard of this game in passing.  Taking a proper look here to see if I might purchase it.  Oh dear!  Rolls‚Ä¶lots of rolls.  Nothing screams arcady ‚Äògame‚Äô more than unrealistic, hyper quick, rolling around, it is silly.  How many real life MMA fighters or soldiers do these chained quick as a blink rolls during battle..oh yeah‚Ä¶NONE. Why? because no one moves THAT fast, and you will be defeated‚Ä¶it is un-immersive to me.  Next‚Ä¶whoosh lines.  Just NO!  No real weapon ever trails any kind of ‚Äòwhoosh‚Äô in the air as it swings, try it with a stick huh!  Oh and while I‚Äôm bitching‚Ä¶The Running ani. More silliness.  Nobody runs with their head tucked down‚Ä¶you‚Äôd fall over.  Sorry Elden Ring‚Ä¶I can‚Äôt take you seriously as a realistic game, which is a shame because I really wanted to <sigh>.

snippet.textDisplay: My advice on Ranged Weapons? DON'T sleep on throwing knifes, kukris, etc. Even bone darts are excellent utility and deal resonable damage, but you can easily farm enough runes to buy hundreds of actual throwing knives from Kale and they can be thrown incredibly fast, deal damge comparable to arrows or bolts and can be used while you have melee weapons equiped. Kukris, while slower, deal even more damge and stack bleed which can be devastating. Those on the other hand can be bought from one the merchants on Weeping Peninsula
snippet.textOriginal: My advice on Ranged Weapons? snippet.textDisplay:
My tip for noobs: Stop stressing about the souls in between bosses. Don't let a small pile of souls prevent you from taking risks and exploring, and don't be afraid of running through especially areas you've died repeatedly in. 

Also get an idea where your character is going build wise. I'm talking about what kind of damage you plan on focusing on. If you need ideas for a build refer to DS3 build guides for things like Bleeding, Quality, Frost etc. All the mechanics and tools from DS3 are in this game and there is a lot of carry over. At the very least, you'll get an idea of what you are doing.
snippet.textOriginal:
My tip for noobs: Stop stressing about the souls in between bosses. Don't let a small pile of souls prevent you from taking risks and exploring, and don't be afraid of running through especially areas you've died repeatedly in. 

Also get an idea where your character is going build wise. I'm talking about what kind of damage you plan on focusing on. If you need ideas for a build refer to DS3 build guides for things like Bleeding, Quality, Frost etc. All the mechanics and tools from DS3 are in this game and there is a lot of carry over. At the very least, you'll get an idea of what you are doing.

snippet.textDisplay:
By hearing how other people speak about Margit, and the fact that there is an item specifically to make him easier that I found today a bit off the beaten path as if you're supposed to step back from the guided route before beating him, I get the sense that people are struggling with him.

I mean after figuring out that the game wanted me to just avoid the tree sentinel and follow where it's guiding you I haven't felt like I needed to look for alternative places to level up a bit before trying again and I think I beat Margit the 3rd or 4th atempt. (2 with a summoned player, 1 as a summon myself but 4th time I decided to try using a spirit instead and then it went pretty smooth.)

So I don't know why but yeah I did not consider him that difficult to beat, I'm not claiming it was easy but you know not hard enough to cause increasing heartrate closer to defeat as if it's unlikely that I'll ever get that far again and a quenched yelp of happy relief once I succeed.
I'll definitely meet atleast one or two of those kinds of encounters in the future though, i guess I just happened to jive well with Margit or something.
Almost for sure one of those bosses everyone else have no issues with is going to give me a hard time to even it out.

snippet.textDisplay:
A couple of additional tips I don't see often mentioned: (Spoiler Free) 
Look for Statues on Cliffs edges/Walls, they have long necks, hunched posture and are pointing, they always point to something secret, look that way.
A little into the game you will be able to alter your characters appearance entirely, so don't worry too much about perfecting your look in character creation, it can be changed freely.
Whilst optional, I recommend you explore ALL of Limgrave before taking on the Castle, the content seems balanced with this in mind, and you may find useful items that will help.
snippet.textOriginal:
A couple of additional tips I don't see often mentioned: (Spoiler Free) 
Look for Statues on Cliffs edges/Walls, they have long necks, hunched posture and are pointing, they always point to something secret, look that way.
A little into the game you will be able to alter your characters appearance entirely, so don't worry too much about perfecting your look in character creation, it can be changed freely.
Whilst optional, I recommend you explore ALL of Limgrave before taking on the Castle, the content seems balanced with this in mind, and you may find useful items that will help.

snippet.textDisplay: By super armor you mean poise. An enemy drops to the ground with a noticeable bass drop sound when you deplete it. Also you can critical attack enemies without depleting their hidden poise meter (or harming them at all). Often that is as simple as circling behind an enemy and hitting R1 when you are so close you are touching them. Or of course from stealth. There are other, enemy specific ways to do so, though
snippet.textOriginal: By super armor you mean poise. An enemy drops to the ground with a noticeable bass drop sound when you deplete it. Also you can critical attack enemies without depleting their hidden poise meter (or harming them at all). snippet.textDisplay: Elden Ring has been my introduction to Soulborne games, and it has been a ROUGH ONE. that said, I've managed to piece together enough to work with to get things done. snippet.textDisplay:
One of my big questions from my early hours with Elden Ring is: why would one ever use the parry instead of the Guard Counter? 
The Guard Counter allows you to keep your guard up, eliminating the risk of mis-timing the parry and taking full damage from the enemy attack. From what I've seen so far, Guard Counter also seems to be just as effective as a parry and riposte. In fact, the Guard Counter is sometimes even BETTER than a parry and riposte, since the Guard Counter attack stuns certain enemies and leaves them open to a riposte.
The only situation that I can think of in which a parry is better than a Guard Counter is if I don't have enough stamina to block an attack without having my guard broken.
Am I missing anything? Is there any other advantage to parry that I'm not aware of?
snippet.textOriginal:

In fact, the Guard Counter is sometimes even BETTER than a parry and riposte, since the Guard Counter attack stuns certain enemies and leaves them open to a riposte.
The only situation that I can think of in which a parry is better than a Guard Counter is if I don't have enough stamina to block an attack without having my guard broken.

snippet.textDisplay: Hey Vaati, I got a quick PSA about group passwords that would be good to pass around. Whenever someone using the same group password as you beats a shardbearer boss, everyone in that group gets a notification as well as that golden weather effect buff. Which I did the math while fighting enemies, and comes out to approximately a 5% boost to runes gained. Which isn't much, but hey every bit counts. And since you can have five group passwords, it is a good idea to pick the passwords that big content creators and streamers are using so you get a steady flow of bonus runes!

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey Vaat. I‚Äôve been a long time subscriber and discovered your channel when you were doing all the Lore behind dark Souls III. I use to lay in my hospital bed and listen to your videos as I tried to fall asleep. During those days I was struggling very heavily with my health and being in that room felt like a never ending eternity. Now that Elden Ring is out, I‚Äôve come back to the channel to get some insight and I‚Äôm happy to see how much you‚Äôve grown and the content has stayed in it‚Äôs amazing quality. Being back here is nostalgic for me, and although the memories are rough, I‚Äôm thankful to be alive. 
Thanks for everything and those nights you gave me other things to think about other than my diagnosis. I‚Äôm happy you‚Äôre still making content. I hope you continue to grow. 
-an old fan

snippet.textDisplay:
Only criticism is that "Super Armor" and "Stagger" are two different concepts to not be confused. 

Super Armor is often used to talk about animations that cannot be interrupted or staggered. Some moves can just plainly not be stopped where others can be, BUT... super armor can be "broken" by filling the stagger meter. Not every attack has super armor!

The "stagger meter" is the invisible meter that fills allowing the use of critical hits. This WILL interrupt attack animations that typically have  super armor, where normal attacks wont.

Super armor is also determined by poise, and each weapon has poise damage that increases depending on overall damage, the weapon type, 1h or 2h, light or heavy attacks. Breaking poise can push through attacks thst usually cant be staggered but will not result in the stagger gauge being filled right away.

This is a beginners guide though so maybe thats a bit complicated to explain to newbros :P

snippet.textDisplay: I think my first playthrough I'll go with pure melee like I always do. Start with the Vagabond and aim for a 40/40/40/40 build and SL 120 for end game and PvP. Once I get an understanding on the new items, spells and combat I can start a second character and really build off into new things. Seems the pure melee might feel the strongest too because you'd have the highest core stats that allow for heavy armour, poise, resistance and stamina.

snippet.textDisplay:
I don't know where that "super-armor" term comes from; never heard it before, and it's potentially rather confusing given its similarity to hyper-armor which is a completely different thing.
The game refers to this as "Stance" and "Stance-breaking". IIRC Sekiro called its similar mechanic "Posture", a clear synonym. 

Anyway, glad we have guys like Vaati and Iron Pineapple to welcome newcomers to the community and show them the ropes. Keep it up, but don't overwork yourself Vaati!
snippet.textOriginal:
I don't know where that "super-armor" term comes from; never heard it before, and it's potentially rather confusing given its similarity to hyper-armor which is a completely different thing.
The game refers to this as "Stance" and "Stance-breaking". IIRC Sekiro called its similar mechanic "Posture", a clear synonym. 

Anyway, glad we have guys like Vaati and Iron Pineapple to welcome newcomers to the community and show them the ropes. Keep it up, but don't overwork yourself Vaati!

snippet.textDisplay: I remember seeing this idea back in Dark Souls when you can choose to go to the catacombs or Undeadburg. snippet.textDisplay: This is a good guide for those starting out. My only addition to it would be, get a lantern. Seriously, while the game is more vibrant than previous Souls game, it does feature a lot of dark locations, from caves to dungeons, even outdoor areas can get dark in places covered with shade/shadows and during the night. The lantern can be acquired relatively early and it helps free your other hand for shield or secondary weapon.
snippet.textOriginal: This is a good guide for those starting out. My only addition to it would be, get a lantern. Seriously, while the game is more vibrant than previous Souls game, it does feature a lot of dark locations, from caves to dungeons, even outdoor areas can get dark in places covered with shade/shadows and during the night. The lantern can be acquired relatively early and it helps free your other hand for shield or secondary weapon.

snippet.textDisplay: This is a game that i have such mixed feelings on it the more time i spend with it. I one hand i really respect and admire the work and ambition that From Software has put into this game. But on the other had for me personally ive been numb to the whole experience so far. The only thing ive really been able to enjoy is riding around the open world and staying out of combat. It probably doesn't help that im just ok at combat in Souls games and i will typically die to things over and over again and never improve.

snippet.textDisplay:
A Prayer For Daily Repentance
Asking for forgiveness should be something you want to do. This prayer is a great guideline for helping you ask Jesus for forgiveness. Make the prayer your own by using the Bible verses that resonated with you the strongest. Begin a conversation with God about your desire to cleanse yourself of evil and you will feel better for it.

Dear Lord, thank you for your forgiveness. Thank you for not abandoning us to our mistakes, but for reaching out instead to bring us home. Help convict me of sin and help me accept your mercy without shame. Thank you for the love you have poured out for me and all of your children. Help me live out of that love today. In Jesus' Name, Amen.

snippet.textDisplay:
Alright, people, Vaati. I need your help enjoying the game.

I‚Äôve loved the souls series since demons souls, just got around to playing Bloodborne and I‚Äôm still diving into the chalices even after getting all three endings.

But I refunded elden ring after the first boss.

It‚Äôs not getting my ass kicked, it‚Äôs not the learning curve. I was so excited at the character creation menu, it‚Äôs got a class I‚Äôve always wanted: the blind seer. I would‚Äôve been playing that and the vagabond to start. I spent an hour creating my character, and once the intro ended, my heart sank: this game looks and feels just Dark Souls 2 to me (character creation looked like DS3, don‚Äôt ask me why). I hated DS2, had to force myself to play it. Elden ring is like a combo of DS2 and Kingdoms of amalur üòû

Do I need to change my graphics (medium)? Why does it look so cartoony? How do I enjoy this game?

If you can be level-headed about this, that‚Äôd be great. Been downvoted a lot on Reddit because I‚Äôve spoken heresy about DS2 or because people couldn‚Äôt handle an opinion they found wrong.

snippet.textDisplay:
I could use a bit of help. The only Souls game I've played extensively is Dark Souls 1 (played DS2 and 3 but never finished them), and playing Elden Ring is making me realize just how much I relied on parries (parries are really easy in DS1) and backstabs to get me through that game. I can handle the regular soldiers fine, but I can barely lay a finger on the patrolling Godrick knight in the Gatefront ruins. My usual strategy for enemies with big shields is to stand in front of them, bait out an attack and then parry, but I can't for the life of me parry a damn thing in this game. Whenever I fight a boss, I feel like I'm constantly on the backfoot, struggling to find safe opportunities to do damage because of how aggressive most of them are.

Does anyone have any good advice for how I can improve? I used the zweihander a lot in DS1, and I know where it is in Elden Ring. Maybe having a weapon I'm familiar with will help?

All four albums is like a connected series. For instance in his when i grow up song, paid my dues, leave me alone,  and why song, the black smile is the fake smile that he mentions in therapy session song. 

He hides eggs in his videos. In when i grow up song there was two hidden eggs in that song. A black balloon by the trash cans and in burger joint he grabbed at receipt that had the date and time of when his song time was being released. He had outcast name tag on in the janitor part from his Outcast song. Another example is in  the search song he had cage in background he rapped in from his outcast song.

snippet.textDisplay:
Are you afraid of death? 
Read this carefully for the cure ;


Every one of us has sinned against God. We‚Äôve lied, we‚Äôve stolen, we‚Äôve sinned sexually, and we‚Äôve taken His name in vain; which makes us liars, thieves, fornicators and blasphemers ... Yet this is only four of our many transgressions .

The problem is, we can never ‚Äòoutweigh‚Äô our sin with good works because God is perfect in Holiness, meaning his standard is beyond our reach. He is also perfect in Justice, meaning, he will bring EVERY sin to light. The punishment for our sin is death, and Hell; a place of Eternal Fire, where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth .

Fortunately God is also perfect in Love; so 2000 years ago, he left his throne in heaven, and came to earth as a man named Jesus Christ. While here, he lived a perfectly righteous life, only to take the punishment that We deserved; Our sinless creator became our sin, and endured a gruesome death on a cross. In doing so, his blood was shed to wash us clean of our transgressions .
Right before he died, he said ‚Äòit is finished‚Äô .. meaning, the debt for our sins has been paid in full. And on the third day, he defeated death and rose from the grave. So now, we can go free from the wrath of God‚Äôs judgement not by earning it, but rather, as a free gift of grace ..

Except gifts can be either accepted or rejected. So this is what you must do in response ; 

Humbly admit to God that you have sinned against him. Then, confess with your mouth that Jesus Christ is Lord, and your Savior. ( Romans 10:9 ) . 

Do this, and you will be saved .

If you do so sincerely, God will grant you a new heart which no longer finds comfort in sin, but instead desires to read and obey his word, the holy bible. He will also grant you Eternal life in his presence; The greatest pleasure on earth doesn‚Äôt even come close to what God is preparing for believers in the afterlife .

You‚Äôve been informed ; Now the choice is yours. What you do with this information will determine where you will be for ETERNITY.. Meaning, this is the single most critical decision you will EVER make .

Jesus Christ awaits you this very moment. Do not put off surrendering your life to him, because your tomorrow isn‚Äôt guaranteed... and as it is written ( Hebrews 9 : 27 ) ;

‚ÄòIt is appointed unto man ONCE to die, but after this, THE JUDGMENT‚Äô.

snippet.textDisplay:
I will say that so far, I despise mounted combat; Torrent always seems to go in the opposite direction of where I want to hit an enemy. Also, if you are stuck head down to the southern peninsula, the castle is much easier than Stormvale, but be wary as many enemies down there inflict madness. And I think that FromSofware is trolling us with how many dog-like enemies there are in the game: big dogs, small dogs, starved dogs, rats that act like dogs, big wolves, small wolves, and many other varieties of dog-like enemies. It is great to see our community of "SEEKERS" growing and guiding each other. 
I am disappointed in FromSoftware with such an easy first boss, Soldier of Godrick, goes down in less than 10 hits on any build.

snippet.textDisplay: A big thing I've noticed about Elden Ring vs other souls games is the number of options you have to get past an obstacle. Reaching a tough boss might not simply require farming to get stronger, it might require using things like different ashes of war that exploit the boss's weakness or using a particular spirit summon. I'm starting to wonder if Margit was so difficult because he was there to break the r1+ dodge only habit that a lot of souls players have and encourage people to use some of the new mechanics. A particular spirit summon made him a lot more manageable, and on my next playthrough I'll probably try to solo him, but it was cool to have an option other than NPC/player summons to beat a boss.
snippet.textOriginal: A big thing I've noticed about Elden Ring vs other souls games is the number of options you have to get past an obstacle. Reaching a tough boss might not simply require farming to get stronger, it might require using things like different ashes of war that exploit the boss's weakness or using a particular spirit summon. I'm starting to wonder if Margit was so difficult because he was there to break the r1+ dodge only habit that a lot of souls players have and encourage people to use some of the new mechanics. A particular spirit summon made him a lot more manageable, and on my next playthrough I'll probably try to solo him, but it was cool to have an option other than NPC/player summons to beat a boss.

snippet.textDisplay: This is my first time playing a souls game (Apart from never beating the first boss of DS3 LOL), and I'm REALLY enjoying it! I think the exploration is my favorite part, and not only that, but after dying to random critters, and then figuring out what I did wrong, and going back and wrecking their shit, like the guard rat things, those goblin creatures etc. I don't think I'll get to the first boss super quickly either, because how much I'm enjoying just the exploration part of the game. Apart from the performance issues on the PC (Which are getting worked on), it's a great game that even if I don't eventually beat, I'm still very much enjoying. Thanks for the great guide! My biggest problem is that I panic in combat, so I just need to remember the flow of combat and how to effectively parry/block, and when and when not to roll. The jump attack is definitely my favorite move set so far in the game as a Confessor.

Apart from the performance issues on the PC (Which are getting worked on), it's a great game that even if I don't eventually beat, I'm still very much enjoying. Thanks for the great guide! My biggest problem is that I panic in combat, so I just need to remember the flow of combat and how to effectively parry/block, and when and when not to roll. The jump attack is definitely my favorite move set so far in the game as a Confessor.

A piece of advice as the Samurai with katanas is when you stagger an enemy instead of immediately going for the critical, continue to flurry with R1 to trigger blood-loss on the downed enemy then quickly finish with the critical.

snippet.textDisplay: If this is your first souls game. Guys please take it slow. You don‚Äôt have to beat your first boss the first night you play it. A boss that was once impossible will be your lil bitch once you figure him out. Have fun. Don‚Äôt give up haha.

Hey all, help me out with this little thought I had when I saw the wretches stats. The wretch class starts at level 1, but you get a base 10 to ALL stats. Granted, other classes give you boosts in other stats, but you start at a higher level. 

Is it then prudent or something to pick the wretch class, where it's cheaper to level up stats from level 1 at the cost of no armor or notable weapons, rather than another class which while giving you a better starting stat in one area and better armor and weapons but a higher starting cost to leveling up?

snippet.textDisplay:
I‚Äôve heard quite a few people talking about returning their copies of the game/not really being able to get into it

As someone who just got into the souls games over the last few months, and has since completed all of them multiple times because i fell on love with the series, I think this video (and others like it) are really important because it‚Äôs like a little pat on the back for new players to encourage them not to give up. Completing one of these games is truly worth the time  investment that comes with the learning curve.

snippet.textDisplay:
Golden tip number 1 for PS5 players.

Manually save your game regularly by exiting the game.

When I got home from work yesterday me and a friend did a huge slog till 5am and my game crashed and the save data was lost too. Had to start all over again and apparently there's a lot of people that have had similar experience. Just a heads up for others
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Another tip is to try and make a good message in a popular area, you get healed whenever someone rates your message saving you the use of a flask. 
Was able to get a somewhat popular message out, currently at 130 likes, i.e. I've recieved 130 free heals, granted many of them happened wheen I was already at full health.
As a Souls veteran I actually consider deleting it as it's almost too OP at times. Unless there's a way to make it not heal me???

snippet.textDisplay: Outstanding guide, thanks a lot.  I've played a lot of souls like games but never a Dark Souls, so I'm struggling with the interface. After 30 years playing videogames, this is the first time i had to search how to equip my armor!!! Yes yes, it is obvious for most players, but I wanted to play as wretched, I have no fear of difficulty but at the very beginning I was totally clueless on where to equip armor! Since those armor slots are grayed out and mixed below weapon slots.  FromSoftware could easily improve this uggly desing.

snippet.textDisplay:
Pretty great guide! I feel like there could've been a mention of localized damage and resistance. Aiming for the head is often dealing a lot more damage and super armor damage(Agheel being defeatable fairly easily with the starting gear as an astronomer thanks to that), and some enemies will be quite easy using sorceries while they'd be too strong for physical damage(stone troll becoming a real pushover) and vice versa(tree sentinel being a nightmare for me with his reflect). So picking the fights most favorable to you is a good idea.

Also, it's nice to have the inputs, but it's not really useful if you're on keyboard sadly. Wish it was using the move names.
snippet.textOriginal:
Pretty great guide! I feel like there could've been a mention of localized damage and resistance. Aiming for the head is often dealing a lot more damage and super armor damage(Agheel being defeatable fairly easily with the starting gear as an astronomer thanks to that), and some enemies will be quite easy using sorceries while they'd be too strong for physical damage(stone troll becoming a real pushover) and vice versa(tree sentinel being a nightmare for me with his reflect). So picking the fights most favorable to you is a good idea.

Also, it's nice to have the inputs, but it's not really useful if you're on keyboard sadly. Wish it was using the move names.

snippet.textDisplay:
For those that started as samurai class; I've found that, with the uchigatana, fighting on the ground vs mounted opponents is more efficient. This is because although you do have a dodge on horseback you have more freedom of movement than the horse does and both unsheathe attacks (LB+RB or R1) let you tag the horse and it's rider when they start to move after an attack. I'd presume that this would also work with GS, UGS, Halberds etc. If they attack fast enough.

Edit: I forgot to mention but obviously it also removes the vulnerability from being dismounted and the extra flasks used to resurrect your mount.
snippet.textOriginal:

This is because although you do have a dodge on horseback you have more freedom of movement than the horse does and both unsheathe attacks (LB+RB or R1) let you tag the horse and it's rider when they start to move after an attack. I'd presume that this would also work with GS, UGS, Halberds etc. If they attack fast enough.

Edit: I forgot to mention but obviously it also removes the vulnerability from being dismounted and the extra flasks used to resurrect your mount.

snippet.textDisplay:
As my first Souls game, Elden Ring taught me valuable life lessons :
- Floating giant blue jellyfishes are not aggressive 
- Mosquitoes will be the death of me
- Feeling greedy and a tad too overconfident ? Ho boy am I about to learn the HARD way, the ANCIENT way, the FROM SOFTWARE way. 
- Backstabbing already ruined my RB button. Player feedback Ruined my Boxers.
- The message system is amazing; how do you warn fellow players about sky diving skeletons ? "Be wary of up" is just the right amount of goofyness and mystery to keep you on your toes.
Seekers' messages helped me a lot, thanks to you all fellow Tarnished üíõ
snippet.textOriginal:

- Feeling greedy and a tad too overconfident ? Ho boy am I about to learn the HARD way, the ANCIENT way, the FROM SOFTWARE way.

snippet.textDisplay:
The hardest part for me is that I picked Bandit, thinking it's like in every souls game, that it does not take long for you to shape your character into whatever class you want, but in Elden Ring I've run around forever with the starting dagger, buckler and barely any level up. Only weapon I found was way above my skills in terms of requirements.


I had to venture into areas that I should not and that kickstarted finally that I get some hard earned (cause of dodging enemies and finding runestones or grinding down stronger solo enemies) levels and found a few weapons. 
For an open world game there is surprisingly less weapons just lying around than there was in the older more linear games it seems.

snippet.textDisplay: This is unrelated, but isn‚Äôt it too much of a coincidence that all of the people serving some sort of greater purpose are blind? The fire keepers in Dark souls (DS3 most notably), the healing church leader Provost Willem and the vicars and more in blood borne, and now the finger maidens in Elden ring. There‚Äôs more to it than just that, and I don‚Äôt want to spoil Elden ring for anyone that hasn‚Äôt played yet, but I feel like there is some crazy inter connectivity that this game is going to reveal.

snippet.textDisplay:
I feel like the most important piece of advice I ever received for a Soulsborne game was; 

"Do not worry about your losing souls. That is all a mind game designed to mess with you. They aren't actually as big of a deal as they seem, and you will always be able to get more. And you will always regain any lost souls much faster then you think you will."

snippet.textDisplay:
Regarding the Spirit Bell.
There seems to be a bug which affects the spawning of the character who gives it to you. On PC at any rate.
If you've been playing for a while and still haven't gotten it, go to the Church of Elleh then find a way to die nearby. You'll respawn at the church and the character should be accessible.

snippet.textDisplay: Tree Sentinel was the most humbling boss for me, I played the samurai class and every engagement ended in about 2 hits. I spent hours fighting him, not moving from the opening area, when I decided to move past him until I get a better shield. I explored caves, cleared out encampments and even fought other mini bosses until I got a 100 physical defense shield. After that I returned and beat Tree Sentinel like he was a walk in the park. If anything Elden Ring taught me that it's okay to explore and return to bosses when you're better equipped. You don't have to slam your head into a brick wall and I think this design philosophy makes it one of, if not the most accessible soulslike to newer players and I'm all for it.
snippet.textOriginal: Tree Sentinel was the most humbling boss for me, I played the samurai class and every engagement ended in about 2 hits. I spent hours fighting him, not moving from the opening area, when I decided to move past him until I get a better shield. I explored caves, cleared out encampments and even fought other mini bosses until I got a 100 physical defense shield. After that I returned and beat Tree Sentinel like he was a walk in the park. If anything Elden Ring taught me that it's okay to explore and return to bosses when you're better equipped. You don't have to slam your head into a brick wall and I think this design philosophy makes it one of, if not the most accessible soulslike to newer players and I'm all for it.

snippet.textDisplay:
For the medium shield guys- circle towards their weapons, clockwise. Never go towards their shields- it's stronger than their weapons for Stam damage. 

For their Leader dude, circle him towards his shield (counter-cockwise). His weapon is his slowest / strongest attack that leaves him open. Shield bash still sucks though, try to avoid it. When he thrusts his spear, stab him in his back.
snippet.textOriginal:
For the medium shield guys- circle towards their weapons, clockwise. Never go towards their shields- it's stronger than their weapons for Stam damage.

snippet.textDisplay: I understand that this is an unpopular opinion, but I was really disappointed by the absolute emphasis on combat in this game.  There is no easier gamemode for those that only want to play casually or who can't keep up with the regular gameplay for whatever reason.  The combat system is pretty convoluted compared to other games, and there is a very steep learning curve that is not at all aided by the short and unhelpful tutorial level.  On top of that, absolutely everything in this game is made deliberately obtuse.  For example, this video was the first time I've had an explanation for what some of the stats actually do in game.  This game is punishing and not in a fun way.  It's stressful and convoluted and obtuse, and while I understand that that is a quality some people enjoy, its disappointing that they couldn't find a way to make this game more accessible to people who enjoy a challenge, but not a sink or swim scenario.

snippet.textDisplay: I'ma be real with this one. Out of all the 'beginning' bosses of any Souls games. Margit seems like the only boss who is a genuine BLOCK. His move pool is just... not a dance between you and him like most bosses. Instead it's... him wildly flailing around and hoping to god you don't die to magic chip damage, or get sucker punched by that stupid ass Magic dagger he has absolutely no reason to have leading to what I'm pretty sure is a vast majority of players overleveling themselves to overcome, rather than learning and skillfully beating his ass.

snippet.textDisplay:
You didn't cover the  biggest boss of them all, the camera. You can't kill what you can't see... or evade... or block, or even reliably comprehend when something can clip over half its body through a wall making it more than a little unintuitive how it's able to move like it does in the arena and what's left in your view is fading out as anything that gets too close to the camera turns invisible.

Seriously, there's the good and the bad with Elden Ring, but one part I've seen on the bad that's shown up multiple times... bosses that are so big you can't really see them with the camera, not all at once at least. I'm used to a few of those each game... gotten a lot in Elden Ring so far though... but the second I wasn't expecting. Bosses that will just clip half way into walls, or in ones case well over half way. Arenas aren't big enough, and boss navigation collision meshes are not at all representative of the bosses themselves in many cases. I feel this might in part be a side effect of our lovely elk/mount. When on that, you are bigger, take up more of the screen, different perspective, it's harder to see normal sized enemies, so it makes sense they'd give you more bigger enemies to fight with it. But that whole bigger enemies mindset (and lore for some related/similar enemies) means many even in more small arenas you fight on foot are exceedingly large. Why not just make the arenas bigger then if they need more space to move around? Idk... honestly I've found tons of areas in the game with lacking polish, especially compared to DS3 that I used as my rough milestone for this game. Don't get me wrong, I'm still enjoying it overall, lots of good fun to be had, HUGE world, but I'm reminded of Yahtees extra credits on fallout 3 and about how its too big a slice of bread and not enough branston pickle.

Very very minor spoilers from very early in the game is a good example. So read on with slight coution if you haven't started playing at all yet, or want NOTHING spoiled (why are you even watching this video or reading comments here then), well. So, in that starting cave/graveyard area you are in, the tutorial area before you come up that elevator to the surface. There is that fog wall you can use one of the lockstone keys on the statue by it to open. Go in there, and there is a boss, there's the spoiler to the extent I'm giving, and that it's too damn big for the arena they gave it, given the moveset it has. Watch how it literally can clip two thirds into the walls even "standing still" and not only during its movement/attack animations. It's the worst example I've so far seen in my early game play. Sure, past dark souls, bloodborne, sekiro bosses aint always perfect and have their oddities, but that one... tell me it doesn't feel like it got enough time and polish, at least if it was from the same development team as the others.

snippet.textDisplay: The entire game so far was built to humble me. I've literally platinumed Bloodborne solo, but I'm about *THIS* close to giving up on Elden Ring, which is a shame because it's beautiful and I'm very interested in the lore. The max healing item limit being 4 at max early game, enemy damage, and super small health pool have halted my progress to a stand still. I'm not bad at the combat, but even with level 19 health I'm getting two shotted by everything if I slip up even for a second, and it's just starting to make me sad. I've beaten three bosses though, so I don't know. Maybe I'm just bad at the game. But if this is what the starting area is like, I don't have much hope of finishing the game. And I really want to because I was so looking forward to it. But now I'm just frustrated and kinda exhausted. Like, what am I doing wrong here?

this is a really shitty port by fromsoftware. I know vaati doesn't talk about this stuff but this time the problem has reached too far. You can see it in steam review aggregate.

There have been very questionable issues. Stuttering is pretty much universal. I don't know, always viewed vaati as a prominent voice in souls community and I feel he can highlight a lot of the glaring issues to prevent this from becoming another disaster like ptde

snippet.textDisplay: I'm gonna be honest and I think the horse control is kind of crap. I mean it's fine when you are on a big open plain, it's way WAY too spastic for precise platforming. It's also kind of annoying how there is no way to slowly reverse the horse without it fully turning around, but the biggest issue with it in my opinion is that it moves way too much whenever you even lightly press toward any direction on the pad. Like if I am standing still and gently angle the analog stick to the right, not only does it turn a full 90 degrees to the right instead of just slightly turning, but it also moves forward 5-10 feet in the direction as well.  They should have made it so that the horse doesn't proceed forward toward any direction at all unless you are holding a specific "go" button (like a gas pedal on car) so that you could have finer directional control over which way Torrent is facing when on smaller platforms. I can't even count how many times now I've fallen off of a platform because the horse decided to commit seppuku by plunging into the massive canyon below when all I wanted to do was angle it like 10 degrees to the left.

Honestly, I just don't think Margit is extremely... balanced, eapecially for a first boss, but thats me not really liking his high mobility and high deeps with holy armor piercing -- and the fact we don't got armor to resist that really early on, but summons do help. Spirits are EXTREMELY useful; use them.

snippet.textDisplay:
haha, neat

And definitely make sure to not immediately fall for the Sellia Tunnel trap before you get the tutorial pop-up that tells you about fast-traveling being in the game.
Else you'd be stuck in a really fucked up area, desperately searching and sneaking around, looking for a way forward, having to face enemies you're nowhere close ready to deal with. And since you wouldn't have unlocked leveling yet, you'd eventually accumulate thousands and thousands of runes you're terrified of losing, yet unable to spend on anything.
And whatever you do, do not spend upwards of 5 hours doing this before randomly finding out about fast-traveling being a thing.
sigh.

haha, neat

And definitely make sure to not immediately fall for the Sellia Tunnel trap before you get the tutorial pop-up that tells you about fast-traveling being in the game.
Else you'd be stuck in a really fucked up area, desperately searching and sneaking around, looking for a way forward, having to face enemies you're nowhere close ready to deal with. And since you wouldn't have unlocked leveling yet, you'd eventually accumulate thousands and thousands of runes you're terrified of losing, yet unable to spend on anything.
And whatever you do, do not spend upwards of 5 hours doing this before randomly finding out about fast-traveling being a thing.
sigh.

snippet.textDisplay: Please, Tarnished Vaati, I beseech the to turn thine eyes to mine prayer!  When the choosing of thy topics commences, I pray thoust enlighten our meagre host regarding the Godlings and the relationship betwixt them. Yea, though their lineage is clear, the duality aspec is most assuredly not. Please, Tarnished Vaati, follow thy path of knowledge towards General Radahn next, for the circumstance of his final cutscene maketh much confusion and consternation.   Should thou addreseth both of these tangled webs, I pray that thoust search thy bountiful mindscape for the truth of the becursed ailment known as the Scarlet Rot and the visitors from beyond the stars.  Verily, the order of inquiry matters not, as thine humble servants are always grateful when receiving thy wisdom on thine own time.  As thou walkest through the valley of the shadow of death, thou wouldst examine thine life and conclude nothing is left, until thou sharest thy knowledge.  We await thy work patiently until thou art ready to impart it to us, thine humble servants.

snippet.textDisplay:
So far so good. Only boss that gave me issues was the fucking tree sentinel. That bitch is built just like Ludwig in bloodborn. Massive, accelerates to mach 3 in an instant closing a football fields worth of distance. Unpredictable attack pattern as he can stop his current attack to shield bash you or shoot holy magic arrows at you that almost always one shot you. Fuck that guy! died to him at least 50 times at level 30 before finally cheesing him through the church opening. After him I attempted margot the fell and while he is strong and hits like a truck he feels very balance, only died to him 5 times. 

Also the tree sentinel is hard to fight on horse back since the starting area is littered with obstacles and large rocks which also makes the boss that much harder.

snippet.textDisplay: Ok I've gotta say this to any person new to playing souls games don't fucking pick wretch. I myself have never played a souls game and wanted to play elden ring because of how amazing it is, I've read lots of comments saying wretch is the best class and even though you start off with nothing it's an amazing experience. It might be amazing to some but for others like myeslf its just not lol, I spent 3 hours struggling just to get to  the first boss. As amazing as elden ring is its very hard and having strong gear at the start can balance it out. I was very frustrated and decided to just start over as a samurai and I had a blast, it was still challenging but I didn't have to worry about not being able to kill a simple soldier. In the end this is just my personal opinion and advice to others that are like me don't take any of it to heart and respect to those that can play the wretch class properly.

snippet.textDisplay:
There are so many that seem to not find the Bell for Spirit Summoning.
I dont 100% know if that is the way to trigger the event. But thats how it went for me:
Go to the Church of Elleh at night. On the North-Eastern broken wall should sit a slightly blue glowing figure, speak to her and you get the Bell.

snippet.textDisplay: A strategy I found very helpful is to equip your flasks to you pouch rather than your quick select. This allows me to simply hold Triangle/Y and then hit right on the d-pad for health, or left for FP. I find this a lot more effective than frantically cycling through quick select in the moment.
snippet.textOriginal: A strategy I found very helpful is to equip your flasks to you pouch rather than your quick select. snippet.textDisplay: This is probably the most frustrating souls game I've played. Most of the open world is useless and boring to traverse. You always fight enemies in groups...they do this to create a false sense of difficulty....instead of being creative they just throw 5 or 6 enemies at you. The boss battles aren't as bad...they're just difficult, because weapon damage in the beginning is a joke. I do enjoy this game....even with all the complaints. I'm just having a difficult time progressing through the game. I find myself quitting out of frustration instead of taking a rest. I'm a little disappointed. The art and enemy design is top notch. I will keep pressing on until I can't any longer. Maybe at some point the game will open up for me and reveal itself in all its glory.
snippet.textOriginal: This is probably the most frustrating souls game I've played. Most of the open world is useless and boring to traverse. You always fight enemies in groups...they do this to create a false sense of difficulty....instead of being creative they just throw 5 or 6 enemies at you. The boss battles aren't as bad...they're just difficult, because weapon damage in the beginning is a joke. I do enjoy this game....even with all the complaints. I'm just having a difficult time progressing through the game. I find myself quitting out of frustration instead of taking a rest. I'm a little disappointed. The art and enemy design is top notch. I will keep pressing on until I can't any longer. Maybe at some point the game will open up for me and reveal itself in all its glory.
